awd_titl_txt: Enabling Algorithms, Signal Processing, and Circuits for Agile Cognitive Radio in CMOS Technology
awd_abstract_narration:
Cognitive radio techniques will be developed that enable rapid, wideband spectrum sensing in the presence of strong interference. Cognitive radios must detect available spectrum quickly in real time with high-probability of success, which requires extremely high dynamic range in the presence of powerful interference signals. Furthermore, future cognitive radio will operate over multiple frequency bands spread out over a wide frequency range. This compounds the challenges to the receiver design since all filtering must be capable of tuning over wide frequency ranges. Finally, the radio must agilely hop among frequency bands. The time required to detect the power in any channel is an overhead that limits the network throughput.

Most prior cognitive radio research applies digital baseband algorithms to conventional RF and analog radio circuitry, which is not designed to address the spectrum sensing application. This limits the achievable spectrum sensing bandwidth and agility and results in high power consumption for the RF, analog, and digital signal processing blocks. This work is fundamentally different in that it will customize the entire receive chain from the RF circuitry through the digital signal processing (DSP) to incorporate new techniques specifically targeted to address spectrum sensing. The techniques involve the injection of pseudonoise-modulated RF signals into the receiver to identify the blockers via correlation algorithms in the DSP as well as to calibrate and cancel the nonlinear characteristics of the receiver. We will develop and refine the proposed algorithms and demonstrate their utility in a 28-nm CMOS receiver integrated circuit.

por.por_cntn:
The research project investigated radio-frequency (RF) circuitry that would allow wireless spectrum to be used more efficiently by more people. The project proposed the investigation of signal processing techniques that could be leveraged in the RF front-end for signal processing specifically targeted to address spectrum sensing. We demonstrated through enabling circuitry and algorithms techniques the potential to inject pseudonoise-modulated RF signals into the receiver to identify the undesirable interference in the form of blockers via correlation algorithms based on digital signal processing (DSP) as well as to calibrate and cancel the nonlinear characteristics of the receiver. We developed and refined the proposed algorithms and implemented these concepts with a prototype in a 45-nm CMOS receiver integrated circuit. While the original target was to use cognitive radio, we found broader application of the circuit and algorithm techniques developed in the program for carrier aggregation in frequency-duplexed systems as well as the use of pseudonoise (PN) modulation to realize full duplex communication.

The intellectual merit of the research project was the investigation of agile, wideband spectrum sensing approaches to monitor wireless frequency bands by leveraging signal processing techniques that utilize the strengths of the RF, mixed-signal, and DSP circuitry in a modern integrated radio. We identified the importance of blocker tagging, nonlinearity characterization, and nonlinearity cancellation to spectrum sensing applications. By looking at the receiver holistically, we developed an architecture for a cognitive radio that outperforms a conventional radio, which performs all spectrum sensing in DSP.  The transformative aspect of the proposed work was the introduction of PN as a beneficial signal in the receiver that can detect changes to the received spectral environment and allow coarse and fine tuning of filters that mitigate interference with very low latency. Furthermore, the PN signals injected into the receiver were used to determine sources of distortion and cancel these through DSP.

The EARS program allowed collaboration between UCSB, UCSD, and UCLA with broader impacts on the approaches to spectrum sharing as well as human resource development. As 5G has become a reality, spectrum sharing techniques for sub-6 GHz bands have remained at the forefront of research as economic and regulatory forces have opened spectrum for wireless access networks (such as 3.5 GHz) and the development of MIMO has pushed the capacity of networks to the spectral efficiency limits. Spectrum sensing is a key enabling technology for cognitive radio systems to enhance network throughput by learning about incumbents or interferers and determining which frequency bands and what physical layer radio parameters to use. During the course of the project, industry trends supported the use of carrier aggregation (CA) whereby multiple bands might be used ad hoc to improve the channel capacity. CA might occur on license bands or with the benefit of an unlicensed band. To assess the benefit of CA, spectrum sensing at the network is required to assess the availability and SNR in the bands of interest.

More than 5 Ph.D. graduate students and 2 undergraduate students were trained under this program who have transferred this training in RF technologies to US-based employers. More than 16 conference and journal research papers were published to disseminate the research outcomes and the research has exposed graduate student researchers to a variety of skills to evaluate modern radio/wireless access techniques for frequency duplexing and full duplex techniques as well as to understand the relationship between communication systems and CMOS devices including design issues for RFICs and DSP techniques for RF bands; a broad set of marketable skills in the current 5G marketplace. Students participating in this program undertook internships with Qualcomm, Analog Devices, Maxlinear, and Skyworks and in many cases joined these firms.
